comment.author: 18213712@N07
comment._content: Reminds me of a Viking long ship

comment.author: 96045361@N00
comment._content: correct spelling is Nordlandsbåt -- Seen in your Photochrom Travel Views set. (?)

comment.author: 26977447@N08
comment._content: And, for clarification, "Nordlandsbåt" is the name of this kind of ship, not a geographical location.

comment.author: 29526620@N06
comment._content: Greeboe, you are very right. The "nordlandsbåt" is considered to be a direct descendant of the Viking long ships. It comes in many sizes and regional variants, but they all look very similar. I believe the type shown on this picture was used in the annual Lofoten cod-fishing campaign, way into the 20th century. A few local boat-builders still do variants of the "nordlandsbåt" today.

comment.author: 34314590@N07
comment._content: Classification of the big boat is "Fembøring" (size). This classification is the bigest of the "Nordlands boat hulls" and was almost used as freight boat belong the coasline in North Norway. The design of hull tell me it`s built in Saltdal.

comment.author: 34314590@N07
comment._content: The small boat classification is "Kjeks". In some disticts of N-N "tororing". The number of room in the boat tell the class of boat. The boat is very fast in the water to row and was also a fast sail boat. The most usual sail was square sail. But it was important with experience for to prevent to capsize. They used enough with ballast with globular stones correct located in the boat. If the boat capsized the globular stones fell out of the boat and it was easy to bring it on keel again.

comment.author: 41853617@N06
comment._content: One thing that this sequence reminds me is how important it is to shoot for tomorrow. Perhaps that's the most useful thing many photographers can do.

comment.author: 34405198@N02
comment._content: This is an Åfjordbåt or Staværing with a topsail. The traditional Nordlandsbåt did not have a topsail. kfr Johan Boyer : Den siste viking  pluss look at Nordland fylkesvåpen.
